article.headline: Tigers win 15th in a row
article.linkText: Pacific backs ranking with dismantling of Idaho
article.story: MOSCOW, Idaho (AP) -- The Pacific Tigers had no trouble backing up their first national ranking against overmatched Idaho. David Doubley scored 21 points to help Pacific beat Idaho 78-56 on Thursday night in the Tigers' first game ever as a member of The Associated Press' Top 25. "This was a good game for us, especially after getting nationally ranked this week," coach Bob Thomason said. "We don't want to be one of those teams that gets ranked and loses and falls out of the rankings." Doubley connected on all five of his 3-point shots as Pacific (19-2, 13-0 Big West) won its 15th game in a row and its 26th consecutive Big West game. "We've had a target on our back the whole season," Doubley said. "Being ranked made it an extra big target. We have to bring our best effort every night." Guillaume Yongo added 14 points and 12 rebounds, and Christian Maraker also scored 14 points for the Tigers. Thomason didn't find much to complain about as the Tigers (No. 23 ESPN/USA Today; No. 24 AP) shot 53 percent while holding Idaho to 36 percent, and outrebounded the Vandals 42-23. "I don't know if we could be playing better than the last two games," Thomason said, referring to last week's 87-58 victory over Long Beach. Idaho (8-15, 6-6) lost for the 10th time in the past 11 games against Pacific. Dandrick Jones led the Vandals with 20 points. "We got beat in every way, shape or form imaginable," Idaho coach Leonard Perry said didn't do a very good job of stopping their big three." He was distressed by the 12 offensive rebounds the Vandals yielded, which led to numerous points for Pacific. "Those things are backbreakers for a team with little margin for error," Perry said. Pacific led by eight points at halftime, then scored the first six points of the second half to build a 45-31 lead. Then Doubley hit a pair of 3-pointers during an 11-0 run that lifted Pacific to a 60-36 lead with 11:05 left. "We just upped our defense," Doubley said. "They kind of wilted under our pressure." Idaho made only two of its first 14 second-half shots, while Pacific hit 10 of its first 16 and outscored the Vandals 27-9 to open the half. The Vandals went 8 minutes without a field goal, and rarely got more than one shot per possession in the second. Idaho shot 26 percent in the second half. In the first half, Dillon Higdon's 3-pointer gave Idaho a 15-13 lead. But 3-pointers by Doubley, Mike Webb and Matt Kemper within a 2-minute span gave Pacific a 24-17 lead with 8:57 left. Higdon's 3-pointer pulled Idaho within 31-27. But baskets by Yango, Doubley and Maraker gave Pacific a 39-31 halftime lead. Pacific was 6-of-12 from 3-point range in the first half. Pacific is 10-1 on the road this season, a school record for road wins. "They get excited about playing on the road," Thomason said. "We really enjoy the environment."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
